pullRequest.body:
add mixins for left and right common multiples. These carry the data of what factors are used to create the common multiples

---

PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise

https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

nodes.body:
### PR summary [bec5d1bd99](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/18461/commits/bec5d1bd9915ac7a68516fd74225ae55c6ca0973)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ CommonAdd`
`+ CommonMul`
`+ LeftCommonAdd`
`+ LeftCommonMul`
`+ RightCommonAdd`
`+ RightCommonMul`
`+ common_left_mul`
`+ common_right_mul`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

Could you please provide a bit more context for this PR? Here are some of the questions that popped in my head while I looked at your PR: Is this part of a larger project? How do you plan to use these definitions? Will you add theory and API lemmas for these new concepts in follow up PRs? How do these new classes interact with the rest of the algebraic hierarchy (monoids/groups/etc)?

> Could you please provide a bit more context for this PR? Here are some of the questions that popped in my head while I looked at your PR: Is this part of a larger project? How do you plan to use these definitions? Will you add theory and API lemmas for these new concepts in follow up PRs? How do these new classes interact with the rest of the algebraic hierarchy (monoids/groups/etc)?

Sure thing!

The Zulip discussion is here: https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/217875-Is-there-code-for-X.3F/topic/common.20left.2Fright.20multiples

I'm working on formalizing a solution to the braid word problem. This approach follows Dehornoy/Garside, and considers first a braid monoid. Then the localization of the (non-commutative) braid monoid is isomorphic to the braid group. Since it's non-commutative, we use the Ore Localization.

This requires the monoid to be cancellative and have (left) common multiples. 

The braid monoid is in fact a presented monoid, and I get some kind of diamond if I try to use the PresentedMonoid instance and the CancelMonoid instance. So instead, I'm planning to use the IsCancelMul mixin. I figured I would need to do something similar for the left-common-multiple property.

This may well be incorrect, and I'd appreciate any advice you have!

```suggestion
theorem common_right_mul : a * RightCommonMul.cr a b = b * RightCommonMul.cr a b :=
```

I think this docstring could be more informative. I have suggested one way to change it, but you should feel free to do something different.
```suggestion
/-- We say that `G` has *left common multiples* if for all `a b : G`, there exist
`c d : G` such that `c * a = d * b`. This mixin carries both the property
of having left common multiples and the data of how to determine `c` and `d` from `a` and `b`.
This will be used to define the left Ore localization of a monoid with respect to itself. -/
```

```suggestion
/-- We say that `G` has *right common multiples* if for all `a b : G`, there exist
`c d : G` such that `a * c = b * d`. This mixin carries both the property
of having right common multiples and the data of how to determine `c` and `d` from `a` and `b`.
This will be used to define the right Ore localization of a monoid with respect to itself. -/
```

```suggestion
/-- We say that `G` has *left common sums* if for all `a b : G`, there exist
`c d : G` such that `c + a = d + b`. This mixin carries both the property
of having left common sums and the data of how to determine `c` and `d` from `a` and `b`. -/
```

```suggestion
/-- We say that `G` has *right common sums* if for all `a b : G`, there exist
`c d : G` such that `a + c = b + d`. This mixin carries both the property
of having right common sums and the data of how to determine `c` and `d` from `a` and `b`. -/
```

pullRequest.title: feat: left and right common multiples mixins
